question_text: Figure 1 shows the structure of a molecule of each of four compounds, A, B, C and D. The formula of a molecule of compound A is H2O. Give the formula of a molecule of compound D.
subject: Chemistry

question_text: Figure 1 shows the structure of a molecule of each of four compounds, A, B, C and D. The names of two of the compounds in Figure 1 are shown below. Draw one straight line from each name to the structure of a molecule of that compound. Name of compound: carbon dioxide, methane.
subject: Chemistry

question_text: Figure 2 shows information about the number of electrons in the outer shell of each of the different atoms in a molecule of compound C. Use the information in Figure 2 to complete the dot and cross diagram for a molecule of compound C.
subject: Chemistry

question_text: The atomic number of phosphorus, P, is 15. One atom of phosphorus has a relative atomic mass of 31. Give the number of protons, neutrons and electrons in this atom of phosphorus.
subject: Chemistry

question_text: A student investigated the temperature change that took place when different salts were dissolved in water. The student used the following method: pour 50 cm3 of water into a polystyrene cup and record the temperature of the water, find the mass of an empty boiling tube, add 2 spatula measures of a salt to the boiling tube and find its new mass, add the salt to the water, stir the mixture and record the temperature after 2 minutes. Use the mass measurements in Figure 4 to calculate the mass of salt, in grams, added to the water.
subject: Chemistry

question_text: The student repeated the method for three different salts, A, B, and C. The same mass of each salt was used. Figure 5 shows the temperature readings obtained for the three different salts. Calculate the temperature change for salt C. Include a sign to show if the temperature change is an increase or a decrease.
subject: Chemistry

question_text: The student repeated the method for three different salts, A, B, and C. The same mass of each salt was used. Figure 5 shows the temperature readings obtained for the three different salts. Explain which salt produces the biggest exothermic change.
subject: Chemistry

question_text: A student investigated the temperature change that took place when different salts were dissolved in water. The student used the following method: pour 50 cm3 of water into a polystyrene cup and record the temperature of the water, find the mass of an empty boiling tube, add 2 spatula measures of a salt to the boiling tube and find its new mass, add the salt to the water, stir the mixture and record the temperature after 2 minutes. Explain why a polystyrene cup is a better container to use for this investigation than a glass beaker.
subject: Chemistry
